book_title: Mastery in the Controls of Recording the Qur'an
text:
Research Abstract: This is a research titled "Mastery in the Controls of Recording the Qur'an." In it, the researcher addressed the issues that hinder the preservation of the Qur'an when "recorded," and established scientific, foundational controls, standards, and criteria for it, consistent with the outcome of the compilation of the Qur'an in its three eras. He addressed this issue in a manner suitable and appropriate for the current challenges in contemporary reality. Then, he warned most severely against boldness towards the Book of Allah in all its forms and shapes, especially reciting it using what are called "Musical Maqamat" (Musical Modes), out of glorification, reverence, and magnification of His Speech - Exalted be He in His Majesty.

PREAMBLE OF THE RESEARCH
Praise be to Allah, who began by praising His Exalted Self before any praiser praised Him. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, to Whom belongs all praise; the One, the Eternal Refuge, who neither begets nor is born, nor is there to Him any equivalent. All the people of His obedience are worshippers of Him, and they are devoutly obedient to Him, standing, bowing, and prostrating. The Living who does not die; the Self-Subsisting who does not sleep; Possessor of Majesty and Honor, and of great and magnificent gifts. He spoke the Qur'an, created man, taught him speech, eloquence, and expression, and bestowed upon His servants guidance and faith. He sent His Messenger Muhammad, peace be upon him, to all mankind and jinn, and supported him with proof and evidence that renew with the renewal of day and night (1); He sent him with a clear Arabic Book,

clear and manifest, and made it a criterion between Monotheism and Polytheism, between guidance and error, darkness and light, doubt and certainty. He revealed it in the briefest wording and most miraculous style, so its rhetoric exhausted the eloquent and its similarity silenced them; its fluency incapacitated the fluent and its opposition baffled them; its wisdom silenced the wise and its contradiction wearied them; its magnificence stunned the orators and its imitation and address incapacitated them. They cannot produce the like of it, even if they assisted one another, as our Lord said regarding that in a clear statement: (Say, "If mankind and the jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Qur'an, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants.") (Al-Isra: 88).

Research Plan:
The researcher included in his research a plan consisting of two chapters. Under each chapter falls a number of sections (Mabahith), and under each section falls a number of requirements (Matalib). In it, he clarified the following:
First: The importance of the research topic.
Second: The most important and prominent previous studies.
Third: Reasons and motives for choosing the research topic.
Fourth: The research problem and its objectives.
Fifth: Research methodology.
Sixth: Conclusion of the research, and a statement of the most important results reached by this brief study.
Seventh: Collection of indexes.

The research plan includes two chapters as follows:
Chapter One: Care for the Qur'an. It contains seven sections:
Section One: The obligation of the Ummah to care for the Qur'an in every aspect. It has two requirements:
Requirement One: The obligation of the Ummah's care for the Audio Compilation of the Qur'an "specifically".
Requirement Two: The duty of the concerned authorities in the Ummah towards individual recordings.
Section Two: The Heart (Spiritual) Controls when recording the Qur'an. It has four requirements:
Requirement One: Sincerity (Ikhlas) in reciting the Qur'an.
Requirement Two: Warning against reciting the Qur'an for other than Allah.
Requirement Three: Classes of people and their states regarding Qur'an recitation.
Requirement Four: Sincerity is from the deeds of the heart.
Section Three: Takhliyah (Emptying/Purifying) and Tahliyah (Adorning) for the reciter of the Qur'an. It has four requirements:
Requirement One: That the reciter be acting upon the Qur'an, characterized by purification (from vices) and adorned (with virtues).
Requirement Two: The stance of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, regarding acting upon the Qur'an.
Requirement Three: The effect of the Qur'an on the souls of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them.
Requirement Four: The stance of the Tabi'in (Successors), may Allah have mercy on them, regarding acting upon the Qur'an.
Section Four: The most important Practical Controls that must be observed when recording the Qur'an. It has eight requirements:
Requirement One: Observing the general rules of Tajweed when recording the Qur'an.
Requirement Two: Absence of affectation and arbitrariness when reading.
Requirement Three: Observing correctness of performance.
Requirement Four: Reading with deliberation and tranquility.

Requirement Six: The quality of mastery of the science of Waqf and Ibtida'.
Requirement Seven: The importance of observing Waqf and Ibtida'.
Requirement Eight: The Salaf's care for Waqf and Ibtida'.
Section Five: Reading with Khushu' (humility), Takhashu' (submission), and presence of heart. It has two requirements:

Requirement Two: How the servant benefits from the Qur'an.
Section Six: Improving the voice in recitation. It has three requirements:
Requirement One: The description of improving the voice in recitation.
Requirement Two: The correct concept of the "Psalms of the Family of David" (Mazamir Al Dawud).
Requirement Three: Improving the voice does not contradict sincerity.
Section Seven: Resolving the dispute between Taghanni (Chanting/Singing) and "Musical Maqamat" (Musical Modes). It has nine requirements:
Requirement One: The concept of the meaning of Tarannum (Humming/Chanting).
Requirement Two: The concept of the meaning of "Music".
Requirement Three: The early vigilance of the Salaf regarding the confusion in the concepts of some terms.
Requirement Four: The decisive word on "Musical Maqamat".
Requirement Five: The consensus of the Salaf on the prohibition of reading the Qur'an with musical tunes.
Requirement Six: The consensus of contemporary scholars on the prohibition of reading the Qur'an with musical tunes.
Requirement Seven: The obligation to purify the Qur'an from "Musical Maqamat", out of glorification, reverence, and magnification of the Speech of Allah.
Requirement Eight: Warning against boldness towards the Book of Allah.
Requirement Nine: Tafkhim (Aggrandizing/Thickening) the voice in recitation.
Chapter Two: The Quranic Ijazah (Authorization) and related matters. It has two sections:
Section One: Controls of the Quranic Ijazah. It has eight requirements:
Requirement One: That the reciter be a Hafiz (memorizer), Mujaz (authorized), and Musnad (having a chain of transmission).
Requirement Two: The concept of Quranic Ijazah.
Requirement Three: The importance of Ijazah.

Requirement Five: Ijazah is a followed Sunnah.
Requirement Six: Prominent figures whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, commended.
Requirement Seven: The value and status of Prophetic commendations.
Requirement Eight: The status of Isnad (Chain of Transmission) in the Religion.
Section Two: That the recording of the Qur'an be by the voice of a "male" man. It has four requirements:
Requirement One: The ruling on a woman's voice.
Requirement Two: Women's Tasbih (saying Subhan Allah) in prayer if in the presence of men.
Requirement Three: Prohibition of women from being soft in speech (Khudu' bil-Qawl).
Requirement Four: Motives for discussing the control of recording the Qur'an (by a "male" man's voice).

Research Methodology
First: Importance of the Research Topic
The importance of the research topic lies in the exposure of Qur'an recording to pests and obstacles that prevent it from being recorded in the correct form, as the compilation ended in its three eras written in hearts and preserved in lines. This research came to set the controls, standards, criteria, foundations, and scientific rules that ensure its preservation when recorded via modern recording means, free from any obvious or hidden error (Lahn), protected from any change, alteration, addition, or decrease, just as it was in the three eras of compilation, in realization of the promise of Allah - Exalted in His Majesty - mentioned in His saying in His decisive verses: (Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian.) (Al-Hijr: 9).

Second: The Most Important and Prominent Previous Studies
The researcher did not find, within the narrow limits of his research, a foundational study that addressed the "Controls of Recording the Qur'an" in an independent, comprehensive scientific research covering all aspects. However, the discussion of some of these controls appeared within the context of the compilation of the Qur'an in its three stages in a number of scientific researches, or was mentioned as a note rather than study, discussion, and verification in others. Among the most prominent of those studies are:
Study One: "The First Audio Compilation of the Holy Qur'an, or, The Chanted Mushaf: Its Motives and Plans", Author: Dr. Labib Al-Said, Publisher: Dar Al-Kitab Al-Arabi for Printing and Publishing - Cairo, Date of Publication: 1387 AH, 1967 AD, (No edition).
Description of the Research: This research is considered the vanguard of the early works of audio compilation of the Holy Qur'an in this era, and this stage is considered the fourth stage of collecting the Qur'an, after

its compilation in its three eras. The history of this collection goes back more than six decades, when its idea crystallized in the heart and mind of the noble Dr. Labib Al-Said (born: 1914 AD - died: 1988 AD). He immediately presented his idea and his gigantic project - which had no precedent in the history of Islam - to the Board of Directors of the General Society for the Preservation of the Holy Qur'an in Cairo, of which he was the chairman at the time. That was specifically in late February or early March 1959 AD. His research (The First Audio Compilation of the Holy Qur'an) came as a scientific and practical translation of this project, the first of its kind in the history of Islam, which Dar Al-Kitab Al-Arabi in Cairo undertook to print in 1387 AH, as we mentioned earlier. The truth is also that this research, despite being a historical research telling the story of the first audio compilation of the Qur'an in the history of Islam, and in which the researcher explains the story of its compilation, motives, causes, goals, objectives, and the obstacles it faced until his dream was realized and his project came to light, and although he presented the imams of recitation in recording the recitations of his project, he, may Allah have mercy on him, did not address the controls of recording the Qur'an. However, the core of his research and the early work in it practically translate many of these controls, even if he did not refer to them verbally or in writing.
Study Two: "Compilation of the Qur'an in its Historical Stages from the Prophetic Era to the Modern Era", Author: Muhammad Shar'i Abu Zaid, Master's Thesis, College of Sharia, Kuwait University, Year of Publication: 1419 AH.
Description of the Research: This research highlights the Muslims' care for preserving the Qur'an from the era of Prophethood until now, confirms that the transmission of the Qur'an received the utmost care from Muslims, and responds to the suspicions of the detractors among the enemies of Islam regarding the transmission of the Holy Qur'an. Due to the quality of the research, its good phrasing, quality of presentation, casting of its style, and strength of its argument, many researchers have benefited from it and drawn from it. The researcher addressed the audio compilation of the Qur'an in the fifth chapter of his research, discussing: its idea, goals, value, plan, execution, and evaluation - only - because it is a sub-research and part of a scientific thesis. As for the controls of its recording and its conditions, he did not address them, because the objectives of his research are related to its title: "Compilation of the Qur'an in its Historical Stages from the Prophetic Era to the Era", and he intended by discussing the audio compilation the beginning of its idea and implementation plan... etc.

Assistant Professor in the Department of Arabic Language and Literature, Research published in the Journal of Research and Studies, Issue Seven, for the year: 2009 AD, affiliated with the Institute of Languages and Literature, University Center - Hama Lakhdar University - El Oued - Algeria.
Description of the Research: This research is not considered a scientific research (in the full sense), but rather an article or research paper because it is very brief, containing only 18 pages. As its author says: It addresses the subject of audio recording of the Qur'an from the beginning of its appearance to our present time, where its author discusses the importance of those recordings recorded by great reciters. His study also dealt with critiquing the chanted Mushafs, revealing some errors that occurred in some of them, so that the listener would be aware of them and not accept everything he hears. He also called for presenting those recordings to specialized committees before broadcasting and publishing them. Despite the small size of this research, the researcher did well and provided benefit. He critiqued some apparent errors that some reciters fell into, noted the importance of benefiting from the recordings of great reciters, and excelled in warning against relying on those recordings for learning because they are auxiliary means and are not considered a source for receiving the Qur'an and learning it alone. There is no doubt that listening to those recordings is extremely beneficial for the learner, but they are not considered a source for reception and should not be relied upon for learning alone, as learning requires receiving orally from the mouths of skilled teachers and sheikhs, just as the Prophet, peace be upon him, received the Qur'an from Gabriel, peace be upon him, and as his Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, received it from him, and as the Tabi'in received it from the Companions. Thus, the Qur'an was transmitted by Tawatur (successive narration) and oral reception from generation to generation until it reached us this way. The researcher was obliged to observe important aspects and pay attention to them, most notably:
1 - His critique of some apparent errors committed by specific reciters by name. It would have been better for him to note the errors without mentioning the reciter's name, because no one is free from error except the infallible one supported by revelation.
2 - His claim that his research: "addresses the subject of audio recording of the Qur'an from the beginning of its appearance to our present time." The observer of his research finds that this statement in the reality of the research does not match its title; rather, he finds it quite far from it because he did not address this subject with research and study, except that he alluded to it - only - and it seems that the brevity of the research played a prominent role in that, and Allah knows best.

3 - It was incumbent upon the researcher to discuss the controls of recording the Qur'an, research them, and study them from all aspects, because the topic of his research is: "Audio Recording of the Qur'an - A Critical Study". The truth is that he did not address the controls of recording the Qur'an, and there is a correlative relationship between these controls and audio recording. He only spoke about the necessity of taking care to control it at the time of its recording - only -, and this is not sufficient at all.

Third: Reasons and Motives for Choosing the Research Topic
As for the reasons and motives for choosing the research topic, they are many, but among the most prominent is the spread of those recorded recitations by large numbers of unqualified reciters through various types and names of modern technical means. So this brief and humble study came to address this phenomenon according to scientific, foundational controls, standards, and criteria appropriate for the current challenges in our present reality, which hinder the emergence of those recordings in the correct form in which the preservation of the Qur'an ended in its three eras.

Fourth: Research Problem and Objectives
A - Research Problem
The research problem lies in the rapid spread of those undisciplined recorded recitations via modern technology like wildfire, despite the obvious and hidden errors (Lahns) they contain between their folds. They have become, for large masses of lay Muslims, sources of reception and sources of learning the Qur'an, due to the appreciation of melodious voices without regard to the quality of recitation and correctness of performance.

B - Research Objectives
This research has great and noble objectives, most notably:
1 - Alerting to the Ummah's responsibility and noting its duty towards the Book of its Lord to rise to care for it and maintain it from every aspect.
2 - Establishing foundations, controls, and scientific and practical ingredients that must be realized in the one for whom the Qur'an is recorded.
3 - Alerting to the duty of the concerned authorities in the Ummah towards undisciplined individual recordings spread via modern technology - specifically.
4 - This study also came to note the reprehensible matters that accompany the audio recording of the Qur'an in general and what is called "Musical Maqamat" in particular.

5 - Just as that study noted the common mistakes during the audio recording of the Qur'an and warned against them, it offered possible and available solutions and alternatives within human capabilities, and held the concerned authorities in Islamic countries responsible to play their constructive role in addressing that phenomenon as much as possible and available, acting upon the Almighty's saying: (So fear Allah as much as you are able) (At-Taghabun: 16).
6 - Establishing controls for the Quranic Ijazah (Authorization) to be the correct path, the straight way, and the final bridge by which one crosses to audio recording.

Fifth: Research Methodology
Descriptive Analytical Approach: The researcher prepared the scientific material related to his research topic "Controls of Recording the Qur'an", then presented it in an analytical presentation arranged according to importance. He then identified the ailment and offered the beneficial remedy for it. As for the most important objectives and most prominent problems of his research, he evaluated, balanced, and countered them by establishing results and appropriate solutions according to the contemporary challenges facing his research topic. He established possible and available solutions capable of addressing his research problem effectively, not formally, and addressed the concerned authorities who hold the power to solve these dilemmas according to the controls, conditions, foundations, and rules he established for recording the Holy Qur'an.

Chapter One: Care for the Qur'an
It contains seven sections:

Section One: The obligation of the Ummah to care for the Qur'an in every aspect
It contains two requirements:

Requirement One: The obligation of the Ummah's care for the Audio Compilation of the Qur'an "specifically"
One of the aspects of glorifying the speech of Allah Almighty is caring for it in every way, and among the greatest of those ways is caring for it when recording it. Just as the Qur'an was cared for in its collection in its three eras, so it was controlled preserved in the hearts, and controlled likewise written in lines, it should likewise be controlled when recording it via diverse contemporary recording means.

Requirement Two: The duty of the concerned authorities in the Ummah towards individual recordings

First: It is known and observed that there are recordings of many different and scattered recitations on radio stations and broadcasting media, the abundance of which only Allah can count.
Second: Among these recordings are those that attained and deserved the degree of mastery but were not subject to the supervision of any specialized, accredited, and trusted scientific body.
Third: Those recordings must be subject to the censorship and supervision of accredited scientific committees of leading specialists, to ensure their production is free from any error on the one hand, and to gain the reassurance of Muslims and their trust in them on the other.
Fourth: If we wanted to compare the fourth compilation of the Qur'an, which is the "Audio Compilation," to its compilation in its second and third eras during the reign of the two Rightly Guided Caliphs, we would find that despite their trust in all the Companions, they formed a committee led by Zaid bin Thabit and established firm foundations, controls, and conditions for it, by which they guaranteed - after Allah's success and help - the production of the Mushaf free from errors.
Fifth: The scientific committees supervising the audio compilation must resemble the compilation committee in its second and third eras. Just as the supervising committee in those two eras was at the highest level of expertise, mastery, honesty, and piety, so too must be the case in the audio compilation committees. Scientific committees should be formed at the highest level from specialists among the scholars of Qira'at (Readings), controlling the script (Rasm), and Tajweed, who are attested for leadership in that by the people of their time, by specialized and accredited scientific bodies. Just as the compilation in these two eras was official by those whom Allah entrusted with the affairs of Muslims, so too must this "Audio" compilation take an "Official" character. And just as printed Mushafs are not printed or published except under the supervision of high official, secure, trusted, and accredited bodies in Islamic countries, such as the King Fahd Complex in Saudi Arabia and Al-Azhar in Egypt, so too must it be for recorded chanted Mushafs, equally, by analogy to the Qur'an compilation committee in its second and third eras to ensure the safety of those recordings that will remain in the hands of Muslims until Allah wills.
Sixth: Therefore, it must be emphasized that individual recordings must be strictly prohibited, and their release, broadcast, and publication to Muslims must be prevented until they are subject to the supervision of specialized and accredited scientific committees - officially - as we mentioned. Thus, the noose is tightened on individual works until they are subject to censorship and scientific supervision from trusted and accredited scientific bodies in the lands of

Section Two: The Heart (Spiritual) Controls when recording the Qur'an
It has four requirements:
Since it is of paramount importance to clarify the most important standards and controls that should be realized in the one for whom the Qur'an is recorded, namely the "Reciter," who must possess the observance of outward etiquette of recitation - which often indicates inward etiquette - and the required quality of performance, it was incumbent upon the researcher to discuss and study those controls according to the following steps:

Requirement One: Sincerity (Ikhlas) in reciting the Qur'an
Sincerity to Allah Almighty is a precious requirement and a precious intent. It is evidence of the servant's righteousness, the truthfulness of his intention, the goodness of his conscience, the purification of his soul, the soundness of his faith, and the truthfulness of his certainty. It is one of the greatest demands of religion. Observance of the aspect of sincerity to Allah Almighty in reciting the Qur'an is one of the greatest matters urged by the purified Sharia, because Allah Almighty does not accept deeds except what is purely for His sake and in accordance with His law. Among that is the recitation of the Qur'an, which is one of the most glorious acts of worship, and acts of worship are built upon sincerity to Allah Almighty; as our Lord, Glory be to Him, said: {And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion, inclining to truth, and to establish prayer and to give zakah. And that is the correct religion.} (Al-Bayyinah: 5).

Requirement Two: Warning against reciting the Qur'an for other than Allah
The Prophet, peace be upon him, warned his Ummah and frightened them greatly, saying in what Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from him: "Indeed, Allah, Blessed and Exalted, when it is the Day of Resurrection, descends to the servants (1), to judge between them, and every nation will be kneeling. The first to be called will be a man who collected (memorized) the Qur'an, a man who was killed in the cause of Allah, and a man of much wealth. Allah Almighty will say to the reciter: 'Did I not teach you what I revealed to My Messenger?' He says: 'Yes, O Lord.' He says: 'So what did you do with what you learned?' He says: 'I used to stand with it (in prayer) during the hours of the night and the hours of the day.' Allah Almighty says to him: 'You have lied,' and the angels say to him: 'You have lied.' Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is a reciter, and that has been said.' And the owner of

Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is generous, and that has been said.' And the one who was killed in the cause of Allah is brought, and Allah says to him: 'For what were you killed?' He says: 'O Lord! I was commanded to strive in Your cause, so I fought until I was killed.' Allah says to him: 'You have lied,' and the angels say: 'You have lied.' Allah says: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is brave, and that has been said.' Then the Messenger of Allah struck my knee and said: 'O Abu Huraira, those three are the first of Allah's creation by whom the Fire will be kindled on the Day of Resurrection.'" (1).
It was said: These three were the first of Allah's creation by whom the Fire is kindled because these acts of worship (learning and teaching Qur'an, Jihad, and spending) are of high status with Allah Almighty; so when their doers did not seek the Face of Allah Almighty with them, but rather sought the immediate [reward] in the world with them, and preferred the perishable in it over the everlasting in the Hereafter; Allah Almighty requited them by making them the first by whom the Fire is kindled; for the punishment is according to the magnitude of the crime. In the Hadith: Warning against Riya' (showing off), and clarification of the severity of its punishment. (2)
And on the authority of Jundub bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever lets (his deeds) be heard, Allah will let him be heard of (expose him), and whoever shows off, Allah will show him off (expose him). (3)
Al-Khattabi (d. 388 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, commenting on this Hadith, said: Meaning: Whoever does a deed without sincerity, only wanting people to see him and hear him, will be requited for that by Allah exposing him and disgracing him, and revealing what he used to conceal and hide of that. And he, peace be upon him, said: "Learn the Qur'an, and ask Allah by it for Paradise, before a people learn it who ask with it for the world. For indeed, the Qur'an is learned by three: a man who boasts with it, a man who eats with it, and a man who reads it for Allah." (5)

One of the greatest things that deter from these blameworthy traits is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And it was already revealed to you and to those before you that if you should associate [anything] with Allah, your work would surely become worthless, and you would surely be among the losers.} (Az-Zumar: 65).

Requirement Three: Classes of people and their states regarding Qur'an recitation
The Prophet, peace be upon him, mentioned the states of people regarding reading the Qur'an, and its effect on them: As established in the Two Sahihs from the hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari - may Allah be pleased with him - who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The likeness of the believer who reads the Qur'an is like the citron (Utrujjah); its fragrance is good and its taste is good. And the likeness of the believer who does not read the Qur'an is like the date; it has no fragrance and its taste is sweet. And the likeness of the hypocrite who reads the Qur'an is like the basil (Rayhanah); its fragrance is good and its taste is bitter. And the likeness of the hypocrite who does not read the Qur'an is like the colocynth (Hanzalah); it has no fragrance and its taste is bitter. (1)
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (d. 852 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Al-Fath": His saying: 'its taste is good, and its fragrance is good'. It was said: The attribute of faith was specified by taste, and the attribute of recitation by fragrance; because faith is more necessary for the believer than the Qur'an, as faith can be obtained without reading. (2)
And on the authority of Iyas bin Amir, he said: Ali bin Abi Talib (d. 40 AH), may Allah be pleased with him, took my hand and said: If you remain, the Qur'an will be read by three classes: a class for Allah, a class for argument, and a class for the world; and whoever seeks by it will attain. (3). Meaning he attained what he read the Qur'an for, and this is a real and observed matter in people's lives.
Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: People in this are of four classes:
The first: The people of the Qur'an and faith, and they are the best of people.
The second: Those who lack the Qur'an and faith.
The third: Those who were given the Qur'an, but were not given faith.
The fourth: Those who were given faith, but were not given the Qur'an.
They said: Just as one who is given faith without the Qur'an is better than one who is given the Qur'an without faith, likewise one who is given contemplation and understanding in recitation is better than one who is given abundance of reading and its speed without contemplation. (4)

In a similar vein, one of the contemporary reciters narrates saying: Our long-lived Sheikh, the Reciter: Abu Munir; Muhammad Al-Sayyid Ismail (1) - may Allah preserve him and prolong his life - narrated to us: "Sultan Abdul Hamid the Ottoman gathered the senior reciters from the regions of the Islamic world in Yildiz Palace, 'which is the palace of the Ottoman Caliphate in Istanbul', and asked to hear from them. The last of them to read was the Reciter Sheikh: Hussein Musa Sharaf al-Din al-Masri al-Azhari 'who is one of the sheikhs of the sheikhs of Sheikh Muhammad, the narrator of the story; who is mentioned in the tree of reciters and was residing in the Badra'iyyah School in Damascus'. After he finished the reading, the Sultan's wife clapped from behind the curtain: indicating that the last reciter should read again. When the Sultan asked the Sheikh to repeat the reading; the Sheikh got angry and refused, saying: 'We read for Allah; and we do not read for So-and-so, and So-and-so'." (2). Where are the reciters of our time compared to this?!
Al-Hasan Al-Basri (d. 110 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: The readers of the Qur'an are three:
The first: A man who took it as merchandise to transport from city to city, seeking with it what people have.
The second: And a people who memorized its letters, and wasted its limits, and sought favors from governors with it, and acted arrogantly with it over the people of their lands.
The third: And a man who read the Qur'an, and started with what he knows of the medicine of the Qur'an, so he placed it on the disease of his heart, so he stayed up his night, and his eyes shed tears, and they clothed themselves in reverence, and wore sadness, and stood in their prayer niches, and persevered in their cloaks. So by them Allah sends down rain, and reveals mercy, and lifts calamity. By Allah, this type among the bearers of the Qur'an is rarer than Red Sulfur. (3)

Requirement Four: Sincerity is from the deeds of the heart
Sincerity is an act of the heart. Although sincerity is one of the acts of the hearts that no one knows except the Knower of the Unseen, Allah has made what points to that in the outward appearance, which indicates what is in the inner self often, namely adorning oneself with Khushu' (reverence) in recitation. Whoever adorns himself with Khushu' in his reading, the effect of that appears on him to those of understanding. That is the confirmation of what Ibn Majah narrated in the Sunan from the hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, among the people with the best voices with the Qur'an is the one whom, when you hear him read, you deem that he fears Allah" (4). There is no doubt that Khushu' is an act of the heart, but Allah manifested it on the limbs.

book_title: Mastery in the Controls of Recording the Qur'an
text:
For worshipping Allah Almighty by reciting the Qur'an is one of the best acts of worship, especially if it is with contemplation, reverence, and acting upon what is in it. In order for reverence to occur in recitation, Allah Almighty commanded good recitation with contemplation. In this Hadith: The Prophet, peace be upon him, informs about that; where he said: "Indeed, among the people with the best voices with the Qur'an", meaning: the best voices in reciting the Qur'an "is the one whom, when you hear him read, you deem that he fears Allah", meaning: that the requirement of improving the voice with the Qur'an is that its reading produces fear of Allah. So whoever you see fear in, has improved the voice with the Qur'an. This is an encouragement from the Prophet, peace be upon him, to improve the voice with it, and to recite it in a measured way (Tartil). If he reads with this description, it is more impactful on the heart and stronger in effect on its listener. (1)
And his saying: (you deem him to fear Allah) means the requirement of improving the voice with the Qur'an is that its reading produces fear of Allah. So whoever you see fear in, has improved the voice with the Qur'an as required legally, so he is counted among the people with the best voices. (2)
Therefore, the fear of falling into Riya' (showing off) in reading must be a motive for the reader to be sincere in his reading, and that matter should not be a discouragement for him from proceeding in reading with reverence and presence of heart; for Satan frightens the servant, brandishing the weapon of Riya' in his face, to induce him to abandon righteous deeds. So the believer reads and improves his reading seeking thereby the Face of Allah Almighty, relying on Him, saying to himself "Abandoning deeds for the sake of people is Riya', and doing deeds for the sake of people is Shirk, and sincerity is that Allah cures you of both" (3). And no one has done a deed except that two impulses passed through his heart (4), if the first of them is for Allah, the latter should not deter him. (5). Ibn Al-Athir (d. 606 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: The meaning is: If he intends an action and his intention in it is correct, then Satan whispers to him saying: 'You intend Riya' by this,' this should not prevent him from doing it. (6)

book_title: Mastery in the Controls of Recording the Qur'an
text:
Sincerity is that people have no share in the worship, and the worshipper does not leave anything of it for their sake. (1). If a person opened upon himself the door of observing people, and guarding against the intrusion of their false thoughts, most doors of goodness would be closed to him, and he would lose a great deal of the important matters of religion for himself. This is not the way of the knowers (of Allah) (2). So let the servant turn to his Lord and seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan, as our Great Lord said: (So when you recite the Qur'an, [first] seek refuge in Allah from Satan, the expelled [from His mercy]. Indeed, there is for him no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord. His authority is only over those who take him as an ally and those who through him associate others with Allah.) (An-Nahl: 98-101). Thus, the intention must be present when reciting the Qur'an, and let his recitation be in response to His command, Glory be to Him, who says in His Noble Book: {I have only been commanded to worship the Lord of this city, Who made it sacred and to Whom [belongs] all things. And I am commanded to be of the Muslims [those who submit to Allah] And to recite the Qur'an. And whoever is guided is only guided for [the benefit of] himself; and whoever strays - say, "I am only [one] of the warners."} (An-Naml: 91-92).

Section: Takhliyah (Emptying/Purifying) and Tahliyah (Adorning) for the reciter of the Qur'an [*]
It has four requirements:

Requirement One: That the reciter be acting upon the Qur'an, characterized by purification (from vices) and adorned (with virtues)
The original motive for this control is what the Rightly Guided Caliph and the First Truthful One, Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, enacted when he chose "Zaid" to carry out the task of the second compilation. He said to him: "You are a young, intelligent man; we do not accuse you, and you used to write the revelation for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. So search for the Qur'an and collect it." (1)
His saying: "we do not accuse you" contains the meaning of Takhliyah (emptying) from everything the soul leans towards, and everything one is accused of regarding invalidating impediments such as breaches of chivalry and shameful traits and characteristics.
And his saying: "and you used to write the revelation for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him" contains the meaning of Tahliyah (adorning), because the Prophet's choice, peace be upon him, of Zaid as a "scribe of revelation" is a commendation for him of the highest commendations. Also, Al-Siddiq's adoption of the method of "Takhliyah and Tahliyah" in his choice of Zaid makes him the first in Islam to enact the sunnah of "Certificate of Experience" after the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him (2). Thereby, trust is established in him and the soul feels reassured towards him.
Also, this description which was combined in Zaid in the first compilation, was adopted and decided by the third Rightly Guided Caliph Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, in the third compilation in his choice of Zaid to undertake the task of the third compilation. In that is an endorsement of what Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, executed and adopted in choosing Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him.

This description that Zaid was characterized with must be characterized by everyone who undertakes it in every era of its eras - likewise -, even if the description is relative between the description of a Companion and the description of others. There is no doubt that the fourth compilation, "The Audio Compilation," falls under the name of "Compilation".

Requirement Two: The stance of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, regarding acting upon the Qur'an
Allah Almighty revealed the Qur'an to His Noble Messenger, peace be upon him, to teach it to his nation, and for it to be a methodology for them in their lives, studying it and acting upon it, obeying its commands and refraining from its prohibitions. On the authority of Jundub bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: We were with the Prophet, peace be upon him, while we were strong youths (Hazawirah), so we learned faith before we learned the Qur'an, then we learned the Qur'an, and we increased in faith by it. (1)
Al-Sindi (d. 1138 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: (Hazawirah) is the plural of Hazwar, and it is said: Hazuwwar with Shaddah on the Waw; it is the boy when he becomes strong, capable, and resolute. So in Al-Sahah, and in Al-Nihayah: It is one who approached puberty. His saying: (and we increased by it) means due to the Qur'an. (2)
Regarding this etiquette, Abu Ubayd Al-Qasim bin Salam Al-Harawi (d. 224 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: The reader of the Qur'an should be keen to act upon what he reads of the Holy Qur'an in his worldly life so that the recitation will be an argument for him on the Day of Resurrection and not an argument against him." (3)
This is the state described by Ibn Umar (d. 73 AH), may Allah be pleased with them both, saying: We lived for a period of our time and one of us would be given faith before the Qur'an. The Surah would be revealed to Muhammad, peace be upon him, and he would learn its lawful and prohibited matters, and what should be stopped at in it, just as you learn the Qur'an. Then he said: I have seen men, one of whom is given the Qur'an and reads what is between its Opening (Fatihah) to its end, not knowing its command nor its deterrent, nor what should be stopped at in it; he scatters it like the scattering of bad dates (Daqal). (4).. (5)

Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (d. 728 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: - The Companions took the wording of the Qur'an and its meaning from the Messenger. Rather, they used to take the meanings from him stripped of their wordings using other wordings, as Jundub bin Abdullah Al-Bajali and Abdullah bin Umar said: We learned faith then we learned the Qur'an, so we increased in faith. He used to teach them faith, which is the meanings revealed in the Qur'an of what is commanded and reported, received with obedience and belief. This is true, for the memorizers of the Qur'an were fewer than the general believers. (1)
The precedence of faith over memorizing the Qur'an in the generation of the Companions contributed to this, because among the first of the Qur'an revealed in the Meccan era were the "Mufassal Surahs" which focus on issues of faith in Allah and the Last Day and establish the creedal aspect upon which the foundation of Islam was built. Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, used to call the Mufassal Surahs "The Core (Lubab) of the Qur'an". "Because what was summarized elsewhere was detailed in them". (2)
On the authority of Aisha, Mother of the Believers, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: "Indeed, the first of what was revealed thereof was a Surah from Al-Mufassal, in which Paradise and Hell are mentioned. Until when the people returned to Islam, the Halal and Haram were revealed. If the first thing revealed was: 'Do not drink wine', they would have said: 'We will never leave wine', and if it was revealed: 'Do not commit adultery', they would have said: 'We will never leave adultery'. Indeed, it was revealed in Mecca to Muhammad, peace be upon him, while I was a young girl playing: (But the Hour is their appointment [for due punishment], and the Hour is more disastrous and more bitter) (Al-Qamar: 46). And Surah Al-Baqarah and An-Nisa were not revealed except while I was with him." (3)
Imam Malik narrated in his "Muwatta" from Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan, that Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, said to a person: "You are in a time where its reciters are few and its jurists are many; the limits of the Qur'an are preserved in it, and its letters are neglected; few are those who ask, many are those who give; they lengthen the prayer, and shorten the sermon; they put their deeds before their desires. And there will come upon the people a time where its reciters are many, its jurists are few; the letters of the Qur'an are preserved in it, and its limits are neglected; many are those who ask, few are those who give; they lengthen the sermon, and shorten the prayer; and they put their desires before their deeds." (4)

Only those among them who collected some Surahs of the Qur'an were considered great, because their custom was acting upon the Qur'an. Therefore, Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, says: "When a man read Al-Baqarah and Al-Imran, he became great in our eyes." (1), meaning: his status became great and his value rose among us, due to his acting upon the requirements of what he memorized.
Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, confirms this meaning saying: The virtuous among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah in the beginning of this Ummah did not memorize of the Qur'an except a Surah or so, and they were blessed with acting upon the Qur'an. But the last of this Ummah read the Qur'an, among them the child and the blind, and they are not blessed with acting upon it. (2)
To achieve this supreme requirement, you see them delaying greatly in memorizing a Surah of the Qur'an. This is not out of inability to memorize or deficiency in that, but rather due to their preoccupation with acting upon what the verses of that Surah indicated. Among that is what Malik narrated from Nafi' from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, learned Al-Baqarah in twelve years; when he finished it, he slaughtered a camel. (3)
This narration shows that the length of Umar's stay, may Allah be pleased with him, in learning Surah Al-Baqarah was not out of inability, laziness, or slackness - far be it from him, and he is of such virtue, status, and precedence in every good and righteousness - but because knowledge of the Qur'an for them was coupled with acting upon it. And here is Ibn Mas'ud (d. 32 AH), may Allah be pleased with him, confirming the same meaning, saying: It was difficult for us to memorize the words of the Qur'an, but easy for us to act upon it; and for those after us, it is easy for them to memorize the Qur'an but difficult for them to act upon it. (4)

Requirement Three: The effect of the Qur'an on the souls of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them
- On the authority of Asma' bint Abi Bakr (d. 73 AH), may Allah be pleased with them both, she said: The Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when the Qur'an was read to them, were as Allah described them: their eyes shed tears and their skins shivered. (1) And they are as Allah described His allies in His saying: (Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And one whom Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide.) (Az-Zumar: 23).
Ibn Manzur (d. 711 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Qusha'rirah (shivering): Trembling. (2)
Ibn Kathir (d. 774 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: His saying: (The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah) means this is the description of the righteous, upon hearing the words of the Compeller, the Hegemon, the Almighty, the Forgiver, because of what they understand from it of promise and threat, and intimidation and warning. Their skins shiver from it out of fear and dread, (then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah) because of what they hope for and expect of His mercy and kindness. They are different from others among the disbelievers in several ways:
First: That the listening of these is the recitation of verses, while the listening of those is melodies of verses, from the voices of singing girls. (3)

Second: That when the verses of the Most Merciful are recited to them, they fall down prostrate and weeping, with manners, fear, hope, love, understanding, and knowledge.
Third: That they adhere to etiquette when hearing it, as the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, were when hearing the Speech of Allah from the recitation of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: their skins shivered, then relaxed along with their hearts at the remembrance of Allah. They did not scream nor feign what was not in them; rather, they possessed stability, calmness, etiquette, and fear such that no one could match them in that; and for this, they won the highest prize in this world and the Hereafter.
Abd al-Razzaq said: Ma'mar told us: Qatadah, may Allah have mercy on him, recited: (The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah) and said: "This is the description of the allies (Awliya) of Allah. Allah described them that their skins shiver, their eyes weep, and their hearts find rest at the remembrance of Allah. He did not describe them with losing their minds and fainting over them. This is only in the people of innovation, and this is from Satan." (1)

Requirement Four: The stance of the Tabi'in (Successors), may Allah have mercy on them, regarding acting upon the Qur'an
The matter was likewise in the generation of the Tabi'in. Regarding this, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, may Allah have mercy on him, says: This Qur'an was read by slaves and boys who have no knowledge of its interpretation, and they did not approach the matter from its beginning. Allah Almighty said: (A Book We have sent down to you, blessed, that they may reflect upon its verses) (Sad: 29), and reflecting upon its verses is nothing but following it. It is not by memorizing its letters and wasting its limits, until one of them says: I have read the whole Qur'an and did not drop a letter from it, while he - by Allah - has dropped it all; you do not see the Qur'an in his character or action. Until one of them says: I read the Surah in one breath. By Allah, these are not reciters, nor scholars, nor wise men, nor pious. When did reciters say such things? May Allah not increase the likes of these among people. (2)

Regarding this, Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, says narrating from some of the Salaf: The Qur'an was revealed to be acted upon, so they took its recitation as an action; therefore, the people of the Qur'an are those who act upon it and act upon what is in it, even if they have not memorized it by heart. As for he who memorized it but did not understand it and did not act upon what is in it, he is not of its people, even if he straightened its letters like the straightening of an arrow. (1)

Section Four: The most important Practical Controls that must be observed when recording the Qur'an
It has eight requirements:

Requirement One: Observing the general rules of Tajweed when recording the Qur'an
Reading the Qur'an with observance of Tajweed rules is one of the most obligatory duties for the reciter to attend to, especially when recording the Qur'an, which will remain until Allah wills, and to which whomever Allah wills of His servants - whose number only He, Glory be to Him, can count - will listen.
Ibn al-Jazari (d. 833 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Al-Nashr": Tajweed is a verbal noun from Jawwada Tajwidan... For them, it is an expression for bringing the reading with improved wording, free from badness in pronunciation. Its meaning is the utmost end in correction and reaching the limit in improvement. There is no doubt that the Ummah, just as they are devoted to understanding the meanings of the Qur'an and establishing its limits, are devoted to correcting its words and establishing its letters according to the quality received from the Imams of Recitation connected to the Prophet, peace be upon him, the most eloquent

Whoever is capable of correcting the words of Allah with the correct, eloquent Arabic pronunciation and deviates to the corrupt, foreign, or ugly Nabatean pronunciation, dispensing with himself, tyrannical with his opinion and guess, relying on what he is accustomed to from his memorization, and arrogant about returning to a scholar who would stop him at the correct pronunciation, is undoubtedly negligent, undoubtedly sinful, and undoubtedly cheating. However, it must be observed that there should be no affectation (Takalluf) or arbitrariness (Ta'assuf) in reading, nor exaggeration in establishing the letters of the Qur'an, nor affectation and pedantry in pronouncing them. This affectation and pedantry was generally forbidden by the Infallible One, peace be upon him, who said: "The extremists (Mutanatti'un) have perished," he said it three times. (3) The Mutanatti'un are: The deep divers, the exaggerators, those who exceed the limits in their words and deeds.
The scholar, Sheikh of Reciters and Literati, Abu al-Hasan Alam al-Din, Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad Al-Sakhawi (d. 643 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said in the opening of his poem titled: ('Umdat al-Mufid wa 'Uddat al-Mujid fi Ma'rifat al-Tajweed) (4):
O you who desire recitation of the Qur'an * And seek the goal of the Imams of mastery
Do not deem Tajweed an excessive elongation * Or stretching what contains no stretch for a moment
Or strengthening a Hamzah after a Mudd * Or chewing the letter like a drunkard
Or uttering a Hamzah while retching * So its hearer flees from nausea
The letter has a balance, so do not be tyrannical * In it, nor be one who causes loss in the balance.
This affectation in establishing the letters of the Qur'an distracts from the highest goal and supreme demand for which the Qur'an was revealed, which is: pondering its verses, acting upon it, complying with its commands, refraining from its prohibitions, preserving its limits, and establishing them as Allah commanded therein.

And Ibn al-Jazari, may Allah have mercy on him (d. 833 AH), said in his Muqaddimah (Introduction):
Perfecting without any affectation * With gentleness in pronunciation without arbitrariness. (1)

Requirement Two: Absence of affectation and arbitrariness when reading
Describing the correct reading, Makki bin Abi Talib Al-Qaisi (d. 437 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: The reader must be moderate in pronouncing it, and not be arbitrary in the intensity of bringing it out when he pronounces it, but bring it out with gentleness and kindness, because it is a letter whose exit is far, so pronouncing it is difficult due to its difficulty. (2)
Ibn al-Jazari, may Allah have mercy on him, says: Tajweed is not chewing the tongue, nor deepening the mouth, nor twisting the jaw, nor trembling the voice, nor stretching the emphasized (Mushaddad), nor cutting the Madd, nor buzzing the Ghunnahs, nor confining the Ra's; a reading that natures shy away from, and hearts and ears reject. Rather, it is the easy, sweet, pleasant, gentle reading, in which there is no chewing, no twisting, no arbitrariness, no affectation, no fabrication, no pedantry, and does not depart from the nature of the Arabs and the speech of the eloquent in any way of the readings and performance. For Tajweed is the ornament of recitation and the decoration of reading. It is giving the letters their rights and arranging their ranks, returning the letter to its exit and origin, attaching it to its like, correcting its pronunciation, and softening the utterance of it in the state of its form and perfection of its shape without excess, arbitrariness, exaggeration, or affectation...
Then he, may Allah have mercy on him, also says: And this is the Sunnah of Allah, Blessed and Exalted, in whomever reads the Qur'an with Tajweed, corrected as revealed: ears delight in its recitation, and hearts humble when reading it, until it almost steals minds and takes hold of intellects; a secret from the secrets of Allah Almighty that He deposits in whom He wills of His creation. We have met among our sheikhs those who had no good voice or knowledge of melodies, except that they were good in performance, upright in wording, so when they read, they thrilled the hearing and captivated the hearts. People used to crowd over them and gather to meet them... while leaving groups of those with beautiful voices knowledgeable in Maqamat and melodies due to their departure from Tajweed

In a similar vein, Abu Shama Al-Maqdisi (d. 665 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: Most of those who seek the Mighty Qur'an have no concern left except for the strength of memorizing it, the speed of reciting it, the refining of pronouncing its words, the search for the exits of its letters, and the desire for a good voice in it. All of this, even if good, above it is what is more important, complete, worthy, and appropriate, which is understanding its meanings, reflecting upon it, acting according to its requirements, standing at its limits, and the fruit of fearing Allah Almighty from proper recitation. (2)
Ibn al-Jawzi (d. 597 AH) warns against this blameworthy affectation, describing the reading of some worshippers, saying, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him: Iblis has confused some worshippers regarding the exits of letters, so you see one saying: Al-Hamd, Al-Hamd. So he exits the canon of prayer etiquette by repeating the word. Sometimes he confuses him in achieving the Tashdid (emphasis), and sometimes in outputting the Dad of Al-Maghdub. I have seen someone saying Al-Maghdub and spitting comes out with the output of the Dad due to the strength of his emphasis. The intent is merely achieving the letter, but Iblis takes these people out by excess beyond the limit of achievement and distracts them with exaggeration in letters from understanding the recitation, and all these whispers are from Iblis. (3)
The Scholar Reciter Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad Al-Nouri Al-Sfaqisi, may Allah have mercy on him (d. 1118 AH), said: Those knowledgeable in the craft of Tajweed used to pronounce it fluently, easily, gently, without arbitrariness, affectation, or severe tone. No one is enabled to do that except through exercise and receiving that from the mouths of the people of knowledge in reading. (4)
Mentioning the categories of the deluded among the people of worship and action, Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali (d. 505 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: Another group: Whispers (Waswasah) overcome them in outputting the letters of Al-Fatihah and other Azkar (remembrances) from their exits. He keeps being cautious in Tashdids (emphases) and the difference between Dad and Za', and correcting the exits of letters in all his prayer, caring for nothing else, not thinking about anything else, oblivious to the meaning of the Qur'an and taking lessons from it and directing understanding to its secrets. This is one of the ugliest types of delusion, for creation was not tasked in reciting the Qur'an with achieving the exits of letters except according to what their custom in speech ran. The example of these is: the example of one who carried a message to the council of a Sultan and was ordered to deliver it properly, so he started delivering the message and being elegant in the exits of letters, repeating them and reiterating them time after time, while being heedless of the purpose of the message and observing the sanctity of the council. How deserving is he to have punishment executed upon him, be sent to the madhouse, and be judged as having lost his mind. (5)
Al-Hafiz Al-Dhahabi (d. 748 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: The reciters who focus on Tajweed: have pedantry and excessive refinement that leads the reciting Mujawwid (one who does Tajweed) to remain focused on observing the letters and being pedantic in their Tajweed, such that it distracts him from pondering the meanings of the Book of Allah Almighty, diverts him from reverence in recitation, and leaves him self-righteous, scorning the memorizers of the Book of Allah Almighty. So he looks at them with an eye of loathing, thinking that Muslims make mistakes (Lahn), and that reciters do not memorize the anomalous (Shadh) readings. I wonder, what have you known and what have you done?! As for your knowledge, it is poor but valid, and as for your recitation, it is heavy, devoid of fear, sadness, and dread. So may Allah Almighty grant you success, show you your right path, and wake you from the sleep of ignorance and showing off. Opposite to them are the reciters of melodies and stretching. Among these, those who read with a heart and fear may provide benefit in general. I have seen among them those who read correctly

As for reading with Narrations (Riwayat) and Combining (Jam'), it is the furthest thing from Khushu' (reverence) and the most intrusive thing upon recitation in a way that removes it from the intent. Their slogan is multiplying the faces of Hamzah, thickening those Lams, and thinning the Ra's. Read, O man, and spare us the thickening and thinning, excessive Imalah and Madds, and stops of Hamzah! How long will this go on?! Another one of them: If he attends a completion (Khatmah) or recites in a niche (Mihrab), his habit is bringing strange faces, silence (Sakt), and retching with Tashil (easing of Hamzah), bringing every disagreement and calling out about himself: "I am Abu... know me, for I am knowledgeable in the Seven." What shall we do with you?! No, and may Allah not give you a good morning, you are a catapult stone and lead upon the hearts. (2).
[Upon this meaning came the speech of others among the people of knowledge. Here is Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, saying while mentioning the machinations of Satan against man: And among that: Whispers (Waswasah) in the exits of letters and pedantry in them... Whoever contemplates the guidance of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and his approval of the people of every tongue in their reading, it becomes clear to him that pedantry, tightening the jaw, and obsession in outputting letters is not from his Sunnah (3)]. [*]

Requirement Three: Observing correctness of performance
The conclusion of this requirement belongs to the Basil of Performance, Sheikh Mahmoud Khalil Al-Husari (d. 1400 AH), where he says, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding the correctness of Tartil (measured recitation):
Tartil: It is improving its words, straightening its letters, and perfecting its performance, by giving every letter its right, and granting it its due of excellence and mastery, verification and goodness. This cannot happen except by correcting the output of every letter from its original exit specific to it, a correction that distinguishes it from what is close to it, and fulfilling every letter's attribute known to it, a fulfillment that distinguishes it from its genus, while easing pronunciation with its true attribute and Quranic form. And with care for clarifying letters, distinguishing some from others, showing Tashdids (emphases), achieving Hamzahs, fulfilling Ghunnahs, completing vowels, and performing each of Izhar, Idgham, Qalb, and Ikhfa' according to its reality reported from the Imams of the Qur'an. And with thickening what must be thickened of letters, thinning what must be thinned of them, shortening what should be shortened, and stretching what is designated to be stretched, and with observing the permissible stops and the prohibited ones; to stop on what is valid to stop on, and connect what is not valid to stop on.

Then he warns the reader against haste and rushing in reading, and directs towards deliberation and tranquility, saying, may Allah have mercy on him:
And provided that all of this - also - is with deliberation and tranquility, and distance from haste and rushing. This manner is the one in which the Holy Qur'an was revealed, and it is what is intended by Tartil which Allah commanded His Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, with in His saying: (And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation.) (Al-Muzzammil: 4). (1)

Requirement Four: Reading with deliberation and tranquility
This control is of paramount importance to avoid any hidden error (Lahn Khafi), as many contemporary reciters have clear and obvious thefts (Ikhtilasat - stealing vowels) that appear to the people of verification and scrutiny from the Imams of performance and masters of recitation at first glance. This is often due to the dialect of the reciter and his upbringing, as local dialects of some countries and tribes are dominated by stealing some movements of letters as is known. The requirement from the reader of the Qur'an is reading with deliberation, tranquility, slowness, and slowness while taking care to clarify the letters, without haste that disrupts reading; as Allah Almighty said: (And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation.) (Al-Muzzammil: 4). Tartil, as is known, is clarifying the letters and showing them, and that cannot be except by outputting them from their exits.
Al-Zajjaj (d. 311 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Recite the Qur'an with Tartil, clarify it clearly. Clarification is not accomplished by rushing in the Qur'an; rather, it is accomplished by clarifying all letters and fulfilling their right of saturation. (2)
Ibn al-Jazari (d. 833 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Tartil is a source from 'ratala fulan kalamahu'; if he followed parts of it with others with a pause... The author of Al-Ain said: "Rataltu al-kalam: I was slow/deliberate in it. (3)

made them three: (Tartil, Tadwir, and Hadr) (1). The origin of the dispute between these sayings goes back to the rank of "Tahqiq". Some make it with Tartil one rank, like Al-Indarabi in "Al-Idah". Some make Tartil a characteristic of Tahqiq, like Al-Dani in "Al-Tahdid" (2). Some make it an independent rank, like Al-Qastalani in "Al-La'ali' Al-Saniyyah" (3). And some see that Tartil is the origin and the other ranks fall under it and emerge from it, so Tartil includes Tahqiq, Hadr, and Tadwir.
Ibn al-Jazari, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Al-Nashr": The speech of Allah Almighty is read with Tahqiq, Hadr, and Tadwir - which is the intermediate between the two states - recited (Murattal) with Tajweed according to the dialects of the Arabs and their voices, and improving the pronunciation and voice as much as possible... Then he proceeded to speak about each rank separately until he said regarding Tahqiq: It is a type of Tartil... And he also said: So Tahqiq enters into Tartil as we presented, and Allah knows best. (4)
The conclusion is that everyone who reads with these three ranks is in reality reciting (Murattil) the Qur'an as Allah commanded, as long as he reads it as Allah commanded him with its rules that were taken orally and transmitted by Tawatur. He is in that complying with His saying: (And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation.) (Al-Muzzammil: 4). The other three ranks are where the reader reads with the rules of Tajweed, but they vary among themselves according to the state of the reader and the situation requiring speed or slowness in reading. The reader might be in a situation where he wants to speed up somewhat, like one who wants to review and adjust memorization for example, or be in Tahajjud prayer in Ramadan or otherwise, so he speeds up while giving letters their due right and entitlement. In another situation, he might want to slow down somewhat, like one who reads with contemplation and scrutiny of the meanings of the verses he recites. He might be in a position of teaching and dictation, so he needs to slow down reading more to clarify the attributes of letters, their exits, their vowels, and the rules of recitation to the learners clearly, so he reads with the rank of Tahqiq. Or the reader might want to read for himself, so he is slightly faster, and so on.

Abu Amr Al-Dani (d. 444 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says in "Al-Tahdid": Tartil is for contemplation, thinking, and deduction; and Tahqiq is for exercising the tongues, thinning the thick words, establishing the reading, and giving every letter its due. (1)
So in all these ranks, the reader reads with deliberation, tranquility, whether he is fast, medium in his speed of recitation, or reading between that. This depends on the context in which he reads (2), as well as the skill of the reader, the exercise of his tongue, and his abundant training and practice with reading. In all those ranks, the reader must take care of the rules of Tajweed. Thus, the ranks of reading in this issue return to the legal interest of what the reader recites.
In a similar vein, Ibn al-Jazari - may Allah have mercy on him - says in "Al-Nashr": I do not know a reason for reaching the end of mastery and Tajweed, and arriving at the limit of correction and precision - like the exercise of tongues, and repetition of the utterance received from the mouth of the benefactor. (3)
As for equality and controlling the amounts of Madds, Ghunnahs, and observing the ranks of Tafkhim and Tarqiq etc., this is a matter that requires reception, adjustment, and presentation orally to the people of mastery among the Imams of recitation, with the obligation of caring for this aspect because, along with its status and value, it is also part of the ornament of recitation. Along with oral reception, there must be training, practice, and exercise until this aspect becomes a second nature in the reader's recitation.

Requirement Five: The reciter's attention to Waqf (Stopping) and Ibtida' (Starting)
The science of Waqf and Ibtida' is one of the most glorious sciences of the Qur'an related to clarifying the facets of the meanings of the Qur'an. It is one of the most important sciences used to understand Allah's intent from His speech. There is no doubt that the reliance of the scholars of Waqf and Ibtida' in placing those known and observed signs in the Mushafs was built upon contemplation of the meanings of the Quranic verses, such that the reader stops and starts according to what is required by the meanings and words upon which it is good to stop or start with. There is no doubt that observing those signs and adhering to them is considered one of the greatest causes aiding the understanding of the speech of Allah and pondering His verses. (1)
Ibn Al-Nakzawi (2) said: The chapter of Waqf is of great destiny, grave importance; because it is not possible for anyone to know the meanings of the Qur'an nor deduce legal evidences from it except by knowing the separators... (3)

This science is a precise and delicate science; few master it and rarely does anyone do it well. Often you hear from some reciters an ugly stop contradicting the intended meaning, disturbing your hearing and saddening your heart. Therefore, the reader of the Qur'an should care about controlling the general rules of Waqf and Ibtida' and pay attention to their precise places, because of the generation of correct meanings resulting from that, for which the signs of Waqf and Ibtida' were placed in the Mushafs. Requirement Six: The quality of mastery of the science of Waqf and Ibtida'
Due to the status and value of the science of Waqf and Ibtida', the Imams of performance mentioned a collection of sciences that must be realized in one who undertakes it completely, leads in it, and masters it with perfection and excellence. Abu Bakr bin Mujahid Al-Tamimi (d. 324 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: No one performs it completely except a grammarian, knowledgeable in Qira'at (readings), knowledgeable in Tafsir (interpretation), knowledgeable in stories and summarizing some from others, knowledgeable in the language in which the Qur'an was revealed. (1)

Requirement Seven: The importance of observing Waqf and Ibtida'
Evidences have combined regarding the importance of observing Waqf and Ibtida'; and quotations indicating the care of the predecessors of the Ummah (Salaf) for this majestic science and its practical application when reciting the Qur'an have abounded. Allah Almighty said: {And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation.} (Al-Muzzammil: 4). This is a command from Allah Almighty to recite the Qur'an with Tartil, and a recommendation from Him, Glory be to Him, to the servants to recite His revealed speech; and observing stops is undoubtedly implicitly included in that.
Ibn Abbas (d. 68 AH), may Allah be pleased with them both, said regarding His saying: {And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation}: (Clarify it clearly) (2). Al-Hasan said: Read it a clear reading. Mujahid said: Some of it following some with deliberation. He also said: (Proceed in it deliberately) (3). Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Read it a reading with slowness, for it aids in understanding the Qur'an and pondering it. (4)
And Allah Almighty said: {The Most Merciful. Taught the Qur'an. Created man, [and] taught him eloquence (Al-Bayan).} (Ar-Rahman: 1-4). Ibn Al-Nahhas (d. 338 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Part of Al-Bayan (clarification) is distinguishing letters and stopping

Ibn Al-Nahhas, Abu Amr Al-Dani, and others have narrated the consensus of scholars on the importance of observing Waqf and Ibtida' (2). They cited as evidence for that the saying of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: We lived for a period of our time... Then he said: I have seen men, one of whom is given the Qur'an and reads what is between its Opening to its end, not knowing its command nor its deterrent, nor what should be stopped at in it; he scatters it like the scattering of bad dates (Daqal) (3).. This narration shows the status of Waqf and Ibtida' among the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and the extent of their care for it in the manner they received from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and that their care for it was like their care for knowing the meanings of the Holy Qur'an and understanding its lawful and prohibited matters. Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, likened the lack of care for reading to the scattering of Daqal, which is bad, dry dates.

Requirement Eight: The Salaf's care for Waqf and Ibtida'
The care of the Salaf (Predecessors), may Allah have mercy on them, for this science became famous to the point that Ibn al-Jazari counted it as Mutawatir (consecutive) from them... Ibn al-Jazari, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Its learning and care for it from the Salaf is authentic, rather Mutawatir with us... until he said: ...and their speech regarding that is known and their texts on it are famous in books. Hence, many of the later Imams stipulated on the licenser (Mujiz) not to license anyone except after his knowledge of Waqf and Ibtida'. Our Imams used to stop us at every letter and point out to us with fingers, a Sunnah for that which they took from their early sheikhs. (5). They used to care for that during recitation teaching.
Scholars have urged learning Waqf and Ibtida' and acting upon it, and explained its great virtue. This is mentioned in the introductions of many books of Waqf and Ibtida', and in many books of the art of Tajweed, and included in books of Quranic sciences. Among what they wrote regarding that is the saying of Ibn Al-Anbari - may Allah have mercy on him -: Part of the completeness of knowing the Qur'an, its meanings, and its strange words is knowing Waqf and Ibtida' in it. Section Four: Reading with Khushu' (humility), Takhashu' (submission), and presence of heart
It has two requirements:

Requirement One: The concept of Khushu' linguistically and legally (Shar'an)
A - Khushu' Linguistically:
Ibn Faris (d. 395 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Khasha'a: The Kha, Shin, and Ayn are one root indicating lowering. It is said: Khasha'a (he humbled) if he lowered and bowed his head. He Yakhsha'u Khushu'an. It is close in meaning to Khudu' (submission), except that Khudu' is in the body... and Khushu' is in the voice and sight. Allah Almighty said: (Their eyes humbled) (Ta-Ha: 108). Ibn Duraid said: The Khashi' (humble one): The submissive and bowing one. (4)
Al-Fairuzabadi (d. 817 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Khushu': Khudu', like Ikhtisha' - and the verb is like Mana'a - or it is close to Khudu', or it is in the body and Khushu' is in the voice and sight. Khushu': Stillness and self-abasement. (5)
Khushu': Submission, stillness, and self-abasement. The verb from it is: Khasha'a; it is said: The person humbled to his Lord: meaning he submitted, became submissive, implored, and abased himself. Khushu' can be in the body, or the voice,

From it is the description of the earth as having Khushu', which is its dryness, lowness, and lack of elevation with irrigation and vegetation. Allah Almighty said: (And of His signs is that you see the earth stilled [Khashi'ah], but when We send down upon it rain, it quivers and swells. Indeed, He who has given it life is the Giver of Life to the dead. Indeed, He is over all things competent.) (Fussilat: 39). (3)
B - Khushu' Legally (Shar'an):
Khushu' in the Sharia is: The submission of the heart and its abasement to Allah - Glory be to Him - as defined by Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him. It was said that it is: Acceptance and compliance with truth and correctness without any prevention, even if the truth differs with desire and wish. Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali added in defining Khushu' that it is: Softness of the heart with tenderness, brokenness, and burning. It should be noted that Khushu' is in the heart, with the manifestation of its effects on the limbs. (4) Among the places where it is appropriate for a Muslim to have Khushu' is during his recitation of the verses of the Holy Qur'an; whether in prayer or outside it, except that in prayer it is more emphasized. (5)
Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The knowers agreed that the locus of Khushu' is the heart, and its fruit is on the limbs, and they display it. (6)
Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali (d. 695 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: The origin of Khushu' is: the heart's tenderness, softness, stillness, submission, brokenness, and burning. If the heart humbles, the humility of all limbs and organs follows it; because they are followers of it, as the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "...Unquestionably, in the body there is a lump of flesh; if it is sound, the whole body is sound, and if it is corrupt, the whole body is corrupt. Unquestionably, it is the heart." (7).
And Takhashu': Feigning Khushu'. (8).

Requirement Two: How the servant benefits from the Qur'an
Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the book "Al-Fawa'id":

For it is a speech from Him to you upon the tongue of His Messenger. Allah Almighty said: (Indeed in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or who listens while he is present [in mind].) Section Six: Improving the voice in recitation
It has three requirements:

Requirement One: The description of improving the voice in recitation
The Qur'an is the speech of Allah, He revealed it to the heart of His Noble Messenger, peace be upon him; to recite it to the people with delay (Mukth); as our Lord said: {And [it is] a Qur'an which We have separated [by intervals] that you might recite it to the people over a prolonged period. And We have sent it down progressively.} (Al-Isra: 106), and his Lord said to him: (And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation.) (Al-Muzzammil: 4).
Al-Qurtubi (d. 671 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said in his Tafsir: Tartil is arranging, coordinating, and good organization. From it is a well-arranged (Ratil/Ratal) mouth (teeth), with Kasra and Fatha on the Ayn: if it is well-arranged. (2)
When the Qur'an is recited, the ears of the believers listen to it, so their hearts submit to it and humble, and their souls guide themselves to its commands and submit, especially if its recitation is from a good voice reciting its verses with Tartil and humility. The texts of the Sunnah have indicated the encouragement of improving the voice in reading the Holy Qur'an. Whoever improves his voice with the Qur'an without affectation or arbitrariness in compliance with the command of the purified Sharia, then excellent is what he did, and he has followed and complied.
