Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Allah has not listened to anything as He listens to a Prophet with a good voice chanting (Yataghanna) the Qur'an, reciting it aloud." (1).
Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Its interpretation - Taghanni - according to the majority like Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad bin Hanbal, and others is improving the voice with it. (2)
So the intended meaning of Taghanni is improving the voice with the Qur'an. Taghanni with the Qur'an is by reciting it aloud with improving the voice with it and having Khushu' in it; to move hearts with it; because among the purposes of reading the Qur'an is moving hearts with it so they are affected, humble, and submit to their Creator; thus benefiting from the Qur'an and its guidance. The meaning of his saying: "Allah has not listened (Ma adhina Allah)"; implies: Allah has not listened (Ma istama'a Allah); and listening here is listening in reality befitting the Essence of Allah Almighty, and it is a listening that does not resemble the listening of created beings, just like all other attributes of the Lord, Glory be to Him - it is said regarding His listening, Glory be to Him, and His permission (Idhn) just as it is said regarding His other attributes, Glory be to Him, and the affirmation of all attributes of the Lord, Glory be to Him, is in the manner befitting Him, Glory be to Him, as our Lord said: (There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing) (Ash-Shura: 11).
Abu Dawud narrated from the hadith of Abu Lubabah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "He who does not chant (Yataghanna) the Qur'an is not one of us" (3). And "whoever does not chant" is whoever does not improve his voice. (4)
Al-Tabari (d. 310 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: What is known in the speech of the Arabs is that Taghanni is indeed singing (Ghina) which is good voice with modulation (Tarji'). (5)
Al-Nawawi (d. 676 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Know that groups of the Salaf used to ask those with good voices in reading to read while they listened. This is agreed upon as desirable, and it is the habit of the righteous, the worshippers, and the righteous servants of Allah. It is an established Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Requirement Two: The correct concept of the Psalms of the Family of David (Mazamir Al Dawud)
It is established in the Two Sahihs that the Prophet, peace be upon him, heard the voice of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari - may Allah be pleased with him - reading at night, so he stopped and listened to his reading, then said: "He has been given a Mizar (Flute/Psalm) of the Mazamir (Psalms) of the family of David" (3). In a narration, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to Abu Musa: "If you could have seen me while I was listening to your reading last night! You have been given a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David" (4). Abu Musa said: "If I knew, O Messenger of Allah, that you were listening to me, I would have adorned it for you greatly (Habbartuhu Tahbira)." (5)
Regarding his saying: "a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David": Al-Nawawi - may Allah have mercy on him - said: The scholars said: The intent by Mizmar here is the good voice. The origin of Zamr is singing. The family of David is David himself, and the family of so-and-so may be applied to the person himself. David, peace be upon him, had a very good voice." (6)
What supports Al-Nawawi's speech and confirms that the intent by Mizmar here is the good voice, not melodies, is his saying - peace be upon him - to Abu Musa (You have been given) - in the passive voice - indicating that the One who granted him the good voice is Allah Almighty, and that he did not acquire it through learning, practice, and exercise.
Ibn Al-Athir - may Allah have mercy on him - said in "Al-Nihayah": In the hadith of Abu Musa, the Prophet, peace be upon him, heard him reading and said: (You have been given a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David). He likened the beauty of his voice and sweetness of his tone to the sound of the Mizmar. David is the Prophet - peace be upon him - and to him belongs the utmost in good voice in reading. (7)
Ibn Khaldun (d. 1332 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: As for his saying - peace be upon him (You have been given a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David), it does not mean repetition and composing melodies (Talhin), rather it means good voice, performance of reading, and clarity in the exits of letters and pronouncing them. (8)

And Abu Musa's saying "I would have adorned it for you greatly" means I would have made it into beautiful types for you, which is Talhin (melodizing), taken from the adorned garment (Thawb Muhabbar), which is striped with colors. Hearts humble to the beautiful voice just as they submit to the beautiful face. What the hearts are affected by in piety is greater in reward and closer to the softening of hearts and removal of hardness from them. Beautiful voices are a blessing from Allah Almighty, an increase in creation, and a favor. The most deserving thing to be clothed in this precious suit and generous gift is the Book of Allah; for the blessings of Allah, if spent in obedience, the right of the blessing has been fulfilled. (1)
Our Eminence Sheikh Imam Ibn Baz (d. 1421 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: The Prophet, peace be upon him, did not deny that from him; this indicates that adorning the voice, improving the voice, and caring for the Qur'an is a required matter; so that the reader and the listener may humble, and this one and that one may benefit. (2).

Requirement Three: Improving the voice does not contradict sincerity
Regarding this, Imam Abu Bakr Al-Ajurri (d. 360 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: It behooves him whom Allah has granted a good voice with the Qur'an to know that Allah has singled him out with a great good; so let him know the value of what Allah has singled him out with, and let him read for Allah, not for creatures. Let him beware of inclining towards being listened to in order to gain favor with listeners out of desire for the world, and inclining towards good praise and status with the sons of the world, and gifts from kings, rather than gifts from common people. Whoever's soul inclines to what I have forbidden him from: I fear that his good voice will be a trial (Fitnah) for him. His good voice only benefits him if he fears Allah Almighty in secret and public, and his intention is that the Qur'an be heard from him so that the heedless wake up from their heedlessness, desire what Allah Almighty encouraged them in, and refrain from what He forbade them. Whoever has this attribute benefits from his good voice, and people benefit from him. (3)

Naming it by other than its name comes from the door of overturning facts to promote falsehood, so that it becomes palatable for the recipient to accept and appreciate it, not magnifying its prohibition, due to what those names - which "overturn facts" from their origin to a palatable mold "verbally" - impart of glittering names, to belittle its atrocity, rudeness, and the severity of its ugliness and prohibition. Satan had the lead in this track, because he was the first to enact that bad sunnah which overturns established facts by changing their implications with other words - out of cunning, deception, lying, and fraud - so that his allies receive and snatch them from him, and inspire one another with decorative speech in delusion, as our Lord said: (And thus We have made for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn, inspiring to one another decorative speech in delusion. But if your Lord had willed, they would not have done it, so leave them and that which they invent.) (Az-Zukhruf: 12). Among the most obvious examples is his overturning of the reality of the tree which Allah forbade the two parents from approaching, so he named it with other than its name; he named it the "Tree of Eternity and a kingdom that does not fade."
Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah have mercy on him in Ighathat al-Lahfan - said: The enemy of Allah only lied to them, deceived them, and tricked them; by naming that tree the "Tree of Eternity". This is the first cunning and plotting, and from it his followers inherited naming forbidden matters with names whose referents souls love. So they named wine the Mother of Joys, and named its sister the Morsel of Comfort (1), and named Usury (Riba) Transaction (Mu'amalah), and named Taxes (Mukus) Royal Rights, and named the ugliest and most obscene injustice the Law of the Divan, and named the most profound disbelief - which is denying the attributes of the Lord - Transcendance (Tanzih), and named gatherings of immorality Gatherings of Goodness! When he named it "Tree of Eternity", he said: Your Lord did not forbid you from this tree except that you become angels or become of the immortal. (2).
When facts are overturned from their intended meanings, one must resort to the language of the Arabs in which the Qur'an was revealed, and with which the most eloquent of creation, peace be upon him, spoke. Whoever contemplates the words in which the Sharia encouraged improving the voice finds them returning to linguistic phrases revolving around this meaning, such as the words "Taghanni with the Qur'an", or other words that appeared on the tongues of some commentators of hadiths in which the Sharia encouraged improving the voice, such as the word "Tarannum", the word "Nagham", and the word "Tatrib". Whoever contemplates those words finds their material revolving around improving the voice in recitation and reciting it aloud only.

We can contemplate the meaning of Tarannum which Al-Zubaidi (d. 1205 AH) cited in Taj Al-Arus where he says - may Allah have mercy on him:
First: He said regarding the meaning of "Tarannum": ((And) Al-Ranam (with vowel movement: The Voice). And Ranim with Kasra: If he modulated (Rajja'a) his voice as in Al-Sahah, (and Al-Ranim and Al-Tarnim: is its Tatrib/Enchanting) as in Al-Muhkam. Al-Jawhari said: And Al-Tarnim: Modulation (Tarji') of the voice). And Tarji' of the voice is: repeating it in the throat. (1)
Second: He said regarding the meaning of "Nagham": (Al-Nagham: with vowel movement, and Sukun: The hidden speech, the singular with Ha'), our Sheikh said: So its singular follows its plural in diacritics, ended. And So-and-so has good Naghmah, meaning: good voice in reading, as in Al-Sahah). And Al-Naghmah: The sound of the word and goodness of voice in reading and otherwise. (2)
Third: He said regarding the meaning of "Ghina" (Singing): ((And Al-Ghina', like Kisa'; from the voice: what is enchanted (Turriba) with) Humaid bin Thawr said: I wondered at it, how can its singing be? And in Al-Sahah: Al-Ghina', with Kasra, is from Sama' (listening). And in Al-Nihayah: It is raising the voice and continuing it. And in Al-Misbah: Its analogy is Damma because it is a sound). Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Ghina is applied to raising the voice, and to Tarannum which the Arabs call (Al-Nasb), and to Huda' (camel singing), and its doer is not called Mughanni (singer); rather, he who recites with stretching, breaking, provoking, and longing containing allusion to obscenities or explicitness is called that. (3)
Fourth: He said regarding the meaning of "Tatrib": (And Al-Tatrib in the voice: extending it and improving it. And Tarraba in his reading: extended and modulated. And the bird Tarraba in its voice likewise. And some of them specified Al-Mukka' with it. And So-and-so: read with Tatrib). (4) And Tarraba in his voice: modulated it, extended it, and improved it. (5)
In light of the linguistic concept of the words Tarannum, Nagham, Ghina, and Tatrib, it becomes clear and evident that they are words indicating improving the voice, its elevation, and its resonance in the throat, and from it Ghina was named Ghina.

Requirement Two: Concept of the meaning of "Music"
As for the word: "Music": It is "a Greek word and has no Arabic root originally. It is a word that accepts masculine and feminine forms, and applies to the arts of playing instruments of Tarab (enchantment)... And music in terminology: A science by which the states of melodies and rhythms are known, and how to compose tunes and create instruments". (1)
It was said: It is a science that discusses the principles of tones in terms of dissonance and harmony, composing melodies, and the states of times that intervene between them. (2)
Taghanni with the Qur'an, improving the voice, and reciting it aloud has no relation to music and its Maqamat. Therefore, the danger of those musical instruments (Ma'azif) and their tools should be known, and that it is not fitting for the recitation of the Qur'an to be linked to them and their Maqamat.

Requirement Three: Penalty for making musical instruments lawful
If a people make musical instruments lawful, they will be transformed into monkeys and pigs. Regarding this, the Prophet, peace be upon him, says: "There will be among my Ummah people who will make lawful Al-Hir (illegal intercourse), silk, wine, and musical instruments (Ma'azif). And people will descend to the side of a mountain; one who goes freely to them (with their flocks) comes to them - meaning the poor - for a need, so they say: Come back to us tomorrow. So Allah destroys them at night, and places the mountain (upon them), and transforms others into monkeys and pigs until the Day of Resurrection." (3)

Imam Abu Amr Ibn Al-Salah (d. 463 AH) narrated the consensus on the prohibition of listening (to music) in "Adab al-Mufti wal-Mustafti", saying, may Allah have mercy on him: Let it be known that the tambourine, flute, and singing, if combined: listening to that is forbidden (Haram) according to the Imams of the schools of thought and other Muslim scholars. It has not been established from anyone whose word is counted in consensus and disagreement that he permitted this listening. (1)
Therefore, scholars of Islam have warned against the danger of those musical instruments most severely. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (d. 728 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Musical instruments are the wine of souls; they do to souls greater than what cups of wine do. If they become intoxicated with sounds, Shirk descends upon them, and they incline towards obscenities and injustice, so they commit Shirk, kill the soul which Allah has forbidden, and commit adultery. These three exist abundantly among the people of listening to musical instruments. (2)
Ibn al-Qayyim (d. 751 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: What we and others have witnessed and known by experiences: Musical instruments and instruments of amusement never appeared in a people and spread among them and they busied themselves with them: except that Allah empowered the enemy over them, and they were afflicted with drought, barrenness, and bad rulers. The wise person contemplates the conditions of the world and observes, and Allah is the One sought for help. (3)
If this becomes clear to us, the prohibition and danger of learning "Musical Maqamat" becomes known, and consequently the prohibition of reading the Qur'an, which is the speech of the Most Merciful, upon the stations (Maqamat) of "Satan". Those who were deluded, erred, and slipped in this chapter mostly did so due to their misunderstanding of the words used by some scholars, such as Tarnim, Taghanni, Tatrib, and similar words, which the scholars defined according to what the language of the Arabs indicated. In this regard, Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari (d. 310 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, says: The meaning of the Hadith is improving the voice and the reasonable singing which is the reciter making the hearer of his voice sad, just as singing with poetry is reasonable singing that thrills its listener.. (4)
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (d. 852 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Improving his voice with it, reciting aloud, chanting (Mutaranniman) on the path of sadness... There is no doubt that souls incline towards reading with Tarannum more than their inclination to one who does not use Tarannum. Because Tatrib has an effect in softening the heart and drawing tears. (5)

So Ibn Jarir interpreted "Taghanni" as singing (Ghina), and Ibn Hajar interpreted improving the voice as "Tarannum" and "Tatrib", but all that was according to what the language indicated. However, the opponents interpreted these words and their likes according to the common, widespread colloquial meaning in people's usage. If they had referred to the meanings indicated by those words in the language of the Arabs, I think the journey would have ended for them and the truth would have appeared clearly to them, if they were among those who search for the truth and strip themselves of desire.

Requirement Three: The early vigilance of the Salaf regarding the confusion in the concepts of some terms
Vigilance of the Salaf regarding this early on: Because of this and similar matters, the prohibition was reported from some of the Salaf regarding narrating some of these Hadiths that contain encouragement for Taghanni with the Qur'an and improving the voice with it, fearing that those texts would be interpreted contrary to their intent, such as what we are dealing with regarding carrying those words to allow engaging in those melodies marked as "Musical Maqamat" which are characteristics of the people of immorality and obscenity who engage in obscene singing accompanied by musical instruments.
Abu Ubayd Al-Qasim bin Salam (d. 224 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan told me from Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj, who said: "Ayyub forbade me to narrate this Hadith: 'Adorn the Qur'an with your voices'" (1). Abu Ubayd - may Allah have mercy on him - said: Ayyub only disliked, as we see, that people would interpret this Hadith as a license from the Messenger of Allah - peace be upon him - regarding these innovative melodies, so for this reason, he forbade him to narrate it. (2)
So interpreting these Arabic words and using them as evidence and proof for the permissibility of using "Musical Maqamat" and reading the Qur'an with them, and permitting them, because similar words appeared in some Hadiths and usage of scholars, is undoubtedly a clear and obvious error. A group of scholars have alerted to this, including: Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, his student Ibn al-Qayyim, Ibn Kathir, and other established scholars.

He also distinguished, may Allah have mercy on him, between natural disposition in reading and blameworthy affectation in Taghanni with the Qur'an until it reaches the limit of stretching (Tamtit), which they do not achieve except through learning, practice, and fabrication, as the people of singing do with melodies and specific rhythms on specific invented weights.
He elaborated on it - may Allah have mercy on him - after citing the silencing evidences by which he demonstrated the invalidity of that heinous act, then he clarified here that Taghanni has a praiseworthy type and a blameworthy type. He said regarding that, may Allah have mercy on him:
The resolution of the dispute is to say that Tatrib and Taghanni are of two types:
One of them: What nature necessitates and allows without affectation, practice, or teaching. Rather, if left to his nature and his disposition flows, it comes with that Tatrib and Talhin (melodizing), then that is permissible. Even if he aids his nature with the grace of decoration and improvement, as Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari said to the Prophet - peace be upon him - "If I knew you were listening, I would have adorned it for you greatly" (1). And the sad person and the one stirred by Tarab, love, and longing cannot help but have sadness and Tatrib in reading, but souls accept it and find it sweet for its agreement with nature and lack of affectation and fabrication in it. It is natural not feigned, inherent not affected. This is what the Salaf used to do and use, and it is the praised, commendable Taghanni, and it is what affects the reciter and the listener. Upon this type, all evidences of the proponents of this view are carried.
The second type: What is a craft among crafts, not allowed by nature, but obtained only by affectation, fabrication, and practice, just as voices of singing are learned with types of simple and compound melodies on specific rhythms and invented weights that are not obtained except by learning and affectation. This is what the Salaf disliked, criticized, blamed, prevented reading with, and denounced whoever read with it. The evidences of the proponents of this view (prohibition) address this type. With this detail, ambiguity is removed and truth becomes distinct from other things. Anyone who has knowledge of the states of the Salaf knows definitively that they are innocent of reading with musical melodies that are affected rhythms and measured, counted, limited movements, and that they are more pious to Allah than to read with them and permit them. He knows definitively that they used to read with sadness and Tatrib, and improve their voices with the Qur'an, reading it with sorrow at times, with Tarab at times, and with longing at times. This is a matter embedded in natures demanding it, and the Lawgiver did not forbid

In a similar vein, Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, says in "Fadail al-Qur'an": The purpose is that what is required by Sharia is only improvement of the voice that incites pondering the Qur'an, understanding it, humility, submission, and compliance with obedience. Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali (d. 695 AH) also noted this in "Nuzhat al-Asma'", saying may Allah have mercy on him: In reality, these innovative, enchanting melodies excite natures and distract from pondering what is obtained from listening, until the pleasure becomes merely hearing the measured tones and enchanting voices. This prevents the intended purpose of pondering the meanings of the Qur'an. The Sunnah only mentioned improving the voice with the Qur'an, not reading with melodies, and there is a wide difference between them. (4)
Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (d. 728 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: It is not permissible for the Qur'an to be read with the melodies of singing, nor to accompany it with melodies that accompany singing from instruments and others, neither according to those who say it is permissible nor according to those who forbid it. Rather, Muslims are agreed on denouncing the coupling of improving the voice in Qur'an with entertaining instruments of the mouth like flutes, and of the hand like tambourines. If someone were to say: The Prophet - peace be upon him - read the Qur'an, and asked Ibn Mas'ud to read it, and listened to Abu Musa's reading, and said: "He has been given a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David" (5), so if someone says: If that was permissible without these melodies, the ruling does not change by hearing it with melodies, this would be a rejected statement and falsehood by the agreement of people. (6)
He said, may Allah have mercy on him, in another place: And the Salaf

Requirement Six: The consensus of contemporary scholars on the prohibition of reading the Qur'an with musical melodies
Contemporary scholars have agreed on the prohibition of reading the Qur'an with musical melodies. Among the most prominent of these are:

Rather, he must read it as our righteous Salaf from the Companions of the Messenger, peace be upon him, and their followers in goodness read it. He should read it with Tartil, sadness, and feigned humility so that it affects the hearts that hear it and so that he is affected by that. As for reading it in the attribute of singers and their way, this is not permissible. (1)
2 - Our Sheikh, the Mark, Saleh bin Fawzan Al-Fawzan - may Allah preserve him -: He was asked what is the ruling on reciting the Qur'an on musical Maqamat? He answered - may Allah preserve him - saying: We seek refuge in Allah from that. It is not permissible to read the Qur'an with melodies and make it songs. These Maqamat are for songs according to the Sufis. It is not permissible to read the Qur'an upon them, nor is it permissible to take the Qur'an as songs. Rather, the Qur'an is recited as the Prophet - peace be upon him - his Companions, and the people of knowledge used to recite it. As for reciting it as the Sufis, innovators, and singers recite it, this is Haram. (2). The saying of our Sheikh Al-Fawzan regarding the obligation of following the example of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his Companions is the same as the saying of our Sheikh Imam Ibn Baz, may Allah have mercy on him, as if it emerged from a single niche.

Requirement Seven: The obligation to purify the Qur'an from "Musical Maqamat", out of glorification, reverence, and magnification of the Speech of Allah
Here are important alerts that should be noted and paid attention to. Finally, after the deficient research in this issue, reference must be made to some important alerts as follows:
First Alert: Reading the Qur'an with those "Maqamat" is an innovated matter that is not based on the practice of the Salaf. Therefore, it is not lawful for a Muslim to read the Qur'an except in the manner by which the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, worshipped Allah Almighty, which he received from the Trustworthy Gabriel, peace be upon him, and taught his Companions, and which was transmitted orally by Tawatur from them until it reached us in the first state in which the Qur'an was revealed.
Second Alert: The Qur'an must be purified from tampering in any form and under any name, especially by what is called "Musical Maqamat", out of glorification, reverence, and magnification of the Speech of Allah, Exalted be He in His Majesty.
Third Alert: Allah revealed the Qur'an to be pondered as He, Glory be to Him, said: ([This is] a blessed Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that they might reflect upon its verses and that those of understanding would be reminded.) (Sad: 29), meaning: that they might ponder the proofs of Allah in it, and what He legislated in it of His laws, so they take heed and act upon it (2). Of the Greatest Calamities: Among the greatest major calamities we heard about in the past is the daring of a famous female singer to record some verses of the Holy Qur'an with her voice. Chapter Two: The Quranic Ijazah (Authorization) and related matters
It has two sections:

Section One: Controls of the Quranic Ijazah
It has eight requirements:

Requirement One: That the reciter be a Hafiz (memorizer), Mujaz (authorized), and Musnad (having a chain of transmission)
Add to the previously mentioned controls: That the reciter intending to record the Qur'an with his voice be among the proficient memorizers to enable quality of pronunciation and lack of stuttering that often afflicts those who have not memorized. And that he be authorized (Mujaz) in the reading or narration he wants to record with his voice from the established Imams of his time and region with a connected chain (Sanad) to the one upon whom the Qur'an was revealed, peace be upon him, who received it from Gabriel, peace be upon him, as Allah Blessed and Exalted clarified in His saying: (And indeed, you are receiving the Qur'an from One, Wise and Knowing.) (An-Naml: 6). His saying (And indeed, you are receiving the Qur'an) means: It is cast upon you, so you receive it, learn it, and take it (3). The mention of the one who taught him and from whom he received it came clearly and explicitly in His saying: (Taught to him by one intense in strength) (An-Najm: 5), and (one intense in strength) is Gabriel, peace be upon him. The Lord of Might, Exalted be He in His Majesty, spoke the Qur'an with letter and voice, and Gabriel, peace be upon him, heard it likewise from the Lord of Might with letter and voice, so he descended with it to the heart of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and conveyed it to him as he heard it. Regarding that, He, Glory be to Him, said: (The Trustworthy Spirit has brought it down * Upon your heart, [O Muhammad] - that you may be of the warners - * In a clear Arabic language.) Requirement Two: The concept of Quranic Ijazah
Quranic Ijazah: It is the process of audio transmission of the Holy Qur'an from generation to generation, in which the licenser (Mujiz) testifies that the recitation of the licensee (Mujaz) has become one hundred percent correct regarding the narration - or narrations - with which he authorized him, then he permits him to read and teach others the Holy Qur'an. (1)
Based on this, the considered Ijazah is one wherein the licensing Sheikh hears from the licensed reciter the entire Qur'an from its opening to its end, letter by letter, receiving it from him part by part.

Requirement Three: The importance of Ijazah
There is no doubt that seeking Ijazah in reading the Holy Qur'an, a correct reading, with a connected chain to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, is a matter praised in Sharia. How could it not be when traveling to seek Hadith was reported from some of the Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them? Traveling to seek mastery of Qur'an recitation is more worthy, and its doer is rewarded and thanked.
The importance of Ijazah is highlighted by the fact that: It is not valid for anyone to teach the Holy Qur'an until he takes it completely from the mouths of knowledgeable, proficient Sheikhs, and is permitted to teach. If he is not permitted to teach, he should not teach the Qur'an even if he read the Qur'an many times. For hearing and presentation are not sufficient for the correctness of performing the Qur'an after the time of widespread Lahn (errors); rather, there must be with them an Ijazah and permission to read and teach. This is because a student might read the entire Qur'an to his Sheikh repeatedly and not master the performance, so the Sheikh does not authorize him. An example of that is what Ibn al-Jazari - may Allah have mercy on him - mentioned about Imam Ahmad bin Ahmad bin Ibrahim Al-Hashimi (d. 646 AH) that Abu Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr read the narration of Warsh to him several complete times (Khatmat), and he said: He did not authorize me, but some of my peers read to him and he authorized them.
Hence: Some of the Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, used to ask some of their students to repeat reading the Qur'an many times until they were certain of their mastery. Among that: Mujahid bin Jabr Al-Makki read to Ibn Abbas thirty Khatmat, stopping him at every verse asking him about it. (2)
Among that: Imam Abu Ja'far presented the Qur'an to his master Abdullah bin Ayyash, and to Abdullah bin Abbas, and to Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with them both.

Requirement Four: The condition of Ijazah for whom the Qur'an is recorded
The condition of Ijazah for one for whom the Qur'an is recorded is that he be authorized by the established Imams of his time and region. This is for several reasons, most importantly:
1 - To ensure lack of leniency in authorization which occurred in later times.
2 - To increase verification of this authorization, due to the fame of the Imams of every era and region among the people of their time and their prominence among them, so authorization of one whom they did not authorize would not be attributed to them.
3 - To push reciters to seek mastery and seek high Isnad (chain) and taking and receiving from the seniors to qualify before coming forward.

Requirement Five: Ijazah is a followed Sunnah
The Prophet, peace be upon him, commended a group of his Companions who received from him and mastered the reading of the Qur'an. The Prophet, peace be upon him, was keen to teach his Companions the Qur'an since the dawn of its revelation in the Cave. Likewise, his Companions were keen to receive and take from him, peace be upon him, and they competed in this field greatly. The star of a number of them shone, so they cared for the Qur'an, learning it, and mastering it until they distinguished themselves in their learning, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, commended them and urged and encouraged receiving and taking from them.

Requirement Six: The status of Isnad (Chain of Transmission) in the Religion
Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak (d. 181 AH), may Allah have mercy on him, said: Isnad is part of the Religion, and were it not for Isnad, whoever wished would have said whatever he wished. If it is said to him: Who told you? He remains... meaning: he remains confused not knowing what to say, because he has no Isnad by which he knows the authenticity or weakness of the Hadith. (2)

Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: Isnad is a virtuous characteristic of the characteristics of this Ummah, and an emphasized Sunnah. We have narrated via Abu al-Abbas Al-Daghuli who said: I heard Muhammad bin Hatim bin Al-Muzaffar say: Allah Almighty has honored, ennobled, and favored this Ummah with Isnad. No one from all the nations, ancient and modern, has a connected Isnad; rather, they have scriptures in their hands, and they have mixed their news with their books, so they have no distinction between what was revealed of the Torah and Gospel and what they attached to their books of news which they took from untrustworthy sources. Requirement: Prominent figures whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, commended [*]
First: Collective Commendations
The Prophet, peace be upon him, commended a group who distinguished themselves in receiving from him. Among those he commended collectively for their precedence and virtue are four persons. It is established in the Two Sahihs that Abdullah bin Mas'ud was mentioned in the presence of Abdullah bin Amr, so he said: That is a man I still love. I heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, say: Take the Qur'an from four: from Abdullah bin Mas'ud - and he started with him -, Salim, the freed slave of Abu Hudhayfah, Mu'adh bin Jabal, and Ubayy bin Ka'b. (1)
These collective commendations for these four Companions are equivalent to an Ijazah (Authorization). His saying (Take the Qur'an from four) is considered an explicit authorization, and is also considered a commendation for them above which there is no commendation, as the command to take from them came in an explicit wording from the Prophet, peace be upon him.
Second: Commendation of Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him:
It is established in the Two Sahihs from the hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to Ubayy: "Indeed, Allah commanded me to read the Qur'an to you." Ubayy said: "Did Allah name me to you?" He said: "Allah named you to me." So Ubayy started weeping. Qatadah said: I was informed that he read to him: (Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture were not...) (Al-Bayyinah: 1). (2)
It is established in Al-Tirmidhi and others with an authentic chain from the hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "...And the most learned of them in the Book of Allah is Ubayy bin Ka'b..." (3). This is undoubtedly an explicit commendation for the Master of Reciters, may Allah be pleased with him.
Third: Commendation of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him:
It is established in Al-Musnad with an authentic chain from Zirr bin Hubaish from a hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: ...Whoever is pleased to read the Qur'an fresh as it was revealed, let him read it according to the reading of Ibn Umm Abd... (4). This is a commendation rarely surpassed, and with that, it is a great and majestic virtue. Here is Abdullah bin Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with him - saying about himself: "By Allah, other than Whom there is no god, no Surah was revealed from the Book of Allah except that I know where it was revealed, and no verse was revealed from the Book of Allah except that I know regarding what it was revealed. And if I knew anyone more knowledgeable than me in the Book of Allah reachable by camels, I would ride to him." (5)
Shaqiq bin Salamah said: Abdullah bin Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with them - addressed us saying: "By Allah, I took from the mouth of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, seventy-odd Surahs. By Allah, the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, knew that I am of the most knowledgeable of them in the Book of Allah, and I am not the best of them." Shaqiq said: So I sat in the circles listening to what they say, and I did not hear a rejector saying otherwise. (6)
Fourth: Commendation of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him:
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, listened to the reading of Abu Musa then said to him: "If you could have seen me while I was listening to your reading last night! You have been given a Mizmar of the Mazamir of the family of David" (7). His eagerness, peace be upon him, to listen to Abu Musa's reading is considered a commendation of the highest commendations.
Fifth: Commendation of Mus'ab bin Umair and Abdullah bin Umm Maktum, may Allah be pleased with them both:
The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Mus'ab bin Umair Al-Abdari and Abdullah bin Umm Maktum, may Allah be pleased with them both, to teach people the Qur'an in Medina before his migration. There is no doubt that sending them for teaching and carrying out this majestic task is considered a commendation for them. It is established in Al-Bukhari from the hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The first who came to us were Mus'ab bin Umair and Ibn Umm Maktum, and they used to teach people recitation... (8).
Sixth: Commendation of Umar bin Al-Khattab and Hisham bin Hakim bin Hizam, may Allah be pleased with them:
Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I heard Hisham bin Hakim bin Hizam reading Surat Al-Furqan, and he read in it letters that the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, had not taught me. I said: Who taught you this Surah? He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. I said: You lied! The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not teach you like this! So I took his hand leading him to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! You taught me Surat Al-Furqan, and I heard this man reading in it letters you did not teach me! The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: Read, O Hisham. So he read as he was reading. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: Thus it was revealed. Then he said: Read, O Umar. So I read. He said: Thus it was revealed. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: Indeed, the Qur'an was revealed in seven letters (Ahruf). (9).
His saying, peace be upon him: "Read, O Hisham"... then his saying: "Thus it was revealed." Then his saying: "Read, O Umar"... then his saying: "Thus it was revealed," this is a commendation for them indicating the correctness of their readings. Other than these commendations, many were narrated on the tongue of the one to whom the Qur'an was revealed, peace be upon him.

Requirement: The value and status of Prophetic commendations [*]
These Prophetic commendations mentioned in the previous hadiths indicate clearly the Prophet's, peace be upon him, commendation of those individuals from his noble Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all. They are commendations equivalent to and having the status of verbal Ijazahs (Authorizations) known among scholars in general and people of recitation in particular. Although they are commendations, they have the ruling of verbal Ijazahs. There is no doubt that those commendations and verbal Ijazahs have their status and value, and even precedence over written Ijazahs. They are considered equivalent to auditory Ijazahs, and have their value and status considering the value and status of the best Licenser and best Licensed. He, peace be upon him, also commended a group of his Companions other than these and praised their reading and recitation as well. Among the most prominent of these is Zaid bin Thabit who - it was said - witnessed the Final Presentation (10) and for that reason Abu Bakr and Umar relied on him in its compilation, and Uthman entrusted him with writing the Mushafs. (11).
Likewise, the commendation of the Scribes of Revelation, and they are a large group. Some of them wrote occasionally, and some of them were consistent in writing revelation, dedicated and specialized in it. Among these scribes were those whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, employed in Mecca before Migration, and some he employed after Migration in Medina and added to them, and some he employed after Al-Hudaybiyah and added to them as well. Mahmoud Shakir mentioned them by name in "Islamic History". (12). Employing these scribes for revelation is considered a commendation surpassed by no other commendation, as the Prophet, peace be upon him, entrusted them with writing the revelation for their knowledge of writing and their good religiosity and honesty.

Section Two: That the recording of the Qur'an be by the voice of a "male" man
It has four requirements:

Requirement One: The ruling on a woman's voice
Scholars differed regarding the ruling on a woman's voice: Is it 'Awrah (nakedness/to be concealed) or not? The correct view in the more authentic of the two scholarly opinions is that the voice of a woman is not 'Awrah in itself at all. This view is what agrees with the general evidences. A woman is only prevented from revealing her voice to non-mahram foreign men without need, just as she is prevented most severely from that in the case of revealing it in a manner of softening (Tarkhim), or having in it melody, softness, stretching, breaking in speech, softening, or tempting coquetry, or in a manner containing informality and intimacy, or in a manner containing clear mixing with laughter and joking, or in any way by which temptation (Fitnah) might occur due to her voice.
It was stated in the Kuwaiti Fiqh Encyclopedia: If it is the voice of a woman, if the listener takes pleasure in it, or fears temptation for himself, listening to it is forbidden for him, otherwise it is not forbidden. The Companions', may Allah be pleased with them, listening to the voices of women when talking to them is interpreted according to this. A woman does not have the right to soften the voice, melodize it, and make it tender, because of what is in it of inciting temptation, due to His Almighty's saying: (then do not be soft in speech [to men], lest he in whose heart is disease should covet, but speak with appropriate speech) (Al-Ahzab: 32) (1). Allah Glorified be He forbade them from softness in speech to prevent Fitnah and lest the people of corruption and desires and those with diseased hearts covet them.

This humble and brief study reached numerous results, the clearest of which are:
1 - That a great duty falls upon the shoulders of the concerned authorities in the lands of Islam regarding the Book of their Lord, especially concerning its recording.
2 - The concerned authorities must pay attention to the fact that anyone who wishes to proceed with recording the Qur'an must possess a set of heart-based, scientific, and practical ingredients and controls.
3 - That reading the Qur'an with what is called "Musical Maqamat" is a reprehensible matter not based on the practice of the Salaf, and the Qur'an must be purified from it. The consensus of the Salaf, and the consensus of contemporary scholars - as well - took place regarding its prohibition.
4 - That the control of Quranic Ijazah (Authorization) with its conditions considered by specialists among the people of knowledge and verification is considered one of the most important controls that must be realized in whoever wishes to proceed with recording the Qur'an.
5 - That the control of recording the Qur'an by the voice of a "male" man does not contain any type of arbitrariness or affectation, nor is it a strange opinion. Rather, it is a fundamental condition and control that has its consideration. The researcher has cited enough transmitted and rational evidence to establish the argument against the opponent, just as he clarified and explained the clear path for whoever wants to follow the path of guidance, the way of righteousness, and follow the path of the believers.
